subject: Re: Pluggable Selector considered harmful? (Re: [junit] Re: Observations from a production use of JUnit4)
msgSnippet: ... But Smalltalk and Ruby are strongly typed languages, so types DO exist. Perhaps you are referring to ManifestTyping
messageBody:
On 02/06/2006 04:02 PM, Cédric Beust ♔ apparently said:
> On 2/6/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > > > You can use Type Inference.
> > >
> > >
> > > Not when you don't have any types :-)
> >
> > True, but my mind was (silently?) focused on dynamic languages like
> > Smalltalk and Ruby.
>
>
> So is mine, and they're both plagued by this problem.
>
> The only dynamically typed language that doesn't have this limitation is
> Groovy, which lets you specify types for your variables if you really want
> to (and most of the time, I really want to -- at least in method
> signatures,
> and then I let type inference do its magic).
>

But Smalltalk and Ruby are strongly typed languages, so types DO exist.
Perhaps you are referring to ManifestTyping
(http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?ManifestTyping). The example I gave was of
Squeak, which is a dialect of Smalltalk.

--
Jason Rogers

Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that
proceedeth out of the mouth of God.
Matthew 4:4


(\ /)
